title: The Evidence Deficit
description: Graduates in non-creative fields (business, analysis) lack tangible artifacts or portfolios to prove their capability beyond their academic transcript. So many people struggle with the ability to sell themselves and a CV is a terrible tool for helping express people's value.
hypothesis: We believe that building a portfolio tool for professionals (lawyers, accountants, doctors, software engineers, management consultants) would have huge popularity if we can be the best solution in the world at that.

evidenceItems.content: The entire interview process is a terrible tool for qualifying somebody's fit and value. So many companies do it wrong. If we had to build a portfolio tool, especially for things like lawyers, accountants, doctors, software engineers, management consultants, I think that there would be huge popularity.

This applies for all ages/stages. The value is very high in the beginning when you lack experience or network. Then as they progress and really do have experience to show, they struggle again to articulate it. So applicable to all life stages, all professions.

evidenceSummary: Highest-scoring problem. Strong hooks around CV building, marketing experience, landing jobs. People are egotistical - helping them see and articulate their value creates high engagement. Strong referral potential as people share their portfolios externally.

applicability.justification: Applies to all life stages, all professions, and all people within our professions. Score: 100%

severity.justification: People struggle significantly to sell themselves and articulate value

frequency.justification: Weekly engagement through task tracking, dynamic portfolio building

willingnessToPay.justification: Very high value - could be strongest feature of the app

retentionImpact.justification: Strong attraction hooks, ability for weekly check-ins, builds rich DNA over time. Score: 5/5

acquisitionPotential.justification: Strong referral ability - people promote their portfolio externally, others discover 2gthr

viralCoefficient.justification: External sharing of portfolios drives viral growth

strategicFit.justification: Could be at the center of the app platform. Differentiates from LinkedIn through personal, holistic growth feed. Score: 5/5

feasibility.justification: Technically achievable with AI/ML for dynamic portfolios

timeToValue.justification: Can build MVP quickly with growth features

riskLevel.justification: LinkedIn competition risk, but differentiated approach

title: The Insight-Action Gap
description: Users consume career content and take assessments but fail to convert that self-knowledge into concrete micro-actions (e.g., sending an email). This is one of the highest value items.
hypothesis: We believe that if we can learn how to get humans to do long-form value creating tasks (similar to how AI agents work), this is a huge business opportunity.

evidenceItems.content: I think everyone struggles to turn insights into action. Even just knowing what to action and how that action drives outcome is something that occurs daily.
I am thinking of this the same way as how to get agents to do long-form value creating tasks. If we can learn how to get humans to do tasks, this is a huge business.

evidenceSummary: Second highest scoring problem. Universal challenge - everyone struggles to turn insights into action. High value if we can crack understanding people's motivations, learning style, action style, and gamification.

applicability.justification: Might be biased but everyone struggles to turn insights into action. Score: 5/5

severity.justification: Occurs daily - knowing what to action and how it drives outcomes

frequency.justification: Daily occurrence for affected users. Score: 5/5

strategicFit.justification: Value heavily dependent on whether we can convince people to follow actions. Depends on understanding motivations, learning style, action style, gamification. Score: 4/5

timeToValue.justification: Requires deep understanding of user psychology

riskLevel.justification: Risk of users not following through

title: Feedback Vacuums
description: Mid-career professionals operate without clear "on-track" signals because managers provide generic performance ratings rather than actionable developmental feedback.
hypothesis: We believe that providing objective KPI tracking and progress signals will bring calm, motivation, and the ability to action insights for professionals at all stages.

evidenceItems.content: This is a problem that presents itself across all stages, all industries. As somebody that was academically weak but had confidence in my ability, I really hated getting graded as my measure of learning.

If we can solve this, it will be one of the most value-felt features. The level of calm it can bring, the motivation, the ability to action insights - super high psychological value. Every employer will want their employees using this tool.

evidenceSummary: Problem exists across all stages but many people don't know it's a problem for them. Very high value if solved - brings calm, motivation, and actionable insights. Challenge is getting users to invest upfront effort to provide info for KPIs.

applicability.justification: Applies across all stages and industries, but not everyone knows they have this problem. Score: 3/5

severity.justification: People struggle with knowing if they're on the right path

frequency.justification: Potential for daily engagement once invested, but high barrier to entry. Score: 3/5

willingnessToPay.justification: If solved, one of the most value-felt features of any app. Score: 5/5

retentionImpact.justification: High if users invest, but engagement barrier exists

acquisitionPotential.justification: Not as strong a hook since people don't know they need it

viralCoefficient.justification: Moderate - employers would want employees using it

strategicFit.justification: Ability to build networks, courses, referrals is very high. Score: 5/5

feasibility.justification: Difficult to gather enough info on jobs, roles, KPIs, managers. Users may not invest effort. Score: 3/5

timeToValue.justification: Slow value delivery due to data collection requirements

riskLevel.justification: Risk that users won't provide required information

title: First 90-Days Failure
description: New hires underperform and face early termination because they lack a structured onboarding plan to manage expectations and secure quick wins.
hypothesis: We believe that providing a differentiated onboarding toolkit using MyDNA, insights-to-action tools, and network mapper will give users a huge advantage.

evidenceItems.content: I see this as a huge referral feature as general company onboarding is shockingly bad. We can build a tool to give users a huge advantage.

evidenceSummary: People aren't actively looking for a solution and it only happens when changing jobs - high cost of acquisition but high referral opportunity for success cases. Daily use for 90 days then hard drop off.

applicability.justification: Not actively searched for, only happens at job changes. High acquisition cost but high referral opportunity. Score: 3/5

severity.justification: Can lead to early termination - high stakes

frequency.justification: Daily use for 90 days then hard drop off if can't keep engaged. Score: 3/5

willingnessToPay.justification: Very high value if we get it right. Score: 5/5

acquisitionPotential.justification: Strong referral opportunity from success cases

strategicFit.justification: Opportunity to build differentiated solution with MyDNA, action tools, network mapper. Builds rich knowledge base. Score: 4/5

feasibility.justification: Can leverage existing MyDNA and tools

timeToValue.justification: Quick value delivery within first week

riskLevel.justification: Risk of engagement drop after 90 days

title: High-Performer Burnout
description: Doctors and CAs experience burnout rates as high as 67% because their professional culture glorifies overwork and stigmatizes rest.
hypothesis: We believe that a tool teaching people a framework for maximizing productivity/decision making, where rest and downtime are tools for being more productive, would be powerful.

evidenceItems.content: If we can rethink of this as a tool for people who view hours as a measure of productivity, there would be a powerful solution to teaching people a framework for maximizing productivity where rest is a tool.
A tool that helps people identify how to get their time back - saying no to work, handing off easy work to juniors, assistants, AI, etc.

evidenceSummary: Relevant to most users but low percentage actively solving it. High engagement if gamified around rest/downtime or outsourcing low-value tasks. High perceived and objective value if solved.

applicability.justification: Relevant to most users but low percentage actively trying to solve it. Score: 3/5

severity.justification: Burnout rates of 67% - severe impact on health and career

frequency.justification: Ongoing effort required for rest. If gamified, high engagement. Score: 4/5

willingnessToPay.justification: High perceived and objective monetary benefit if coaching high-value people. Score: 4/5

retentionImpact.justification: Active, ongoing effort required - good for retention

acquisitionPotential.justification: Lower since people don't actively search for burnout solutions

strategicFit.justification: Cool tools, dashboards, courses possible. If using us for work, builds strong user understanding. Score: 4/5

feasibility.justification: Challenge balancing demand to bill hours with rest

riskLevel.justification: Risk of users not trusting/using the solution

title: Offer Negotiation Illiteracy
description: Entry-level professionals accept the first offer they receive without understanding how to evaluate or negotiate total compensation (benefits, learning, equity).
hypothesis: We believe this extends beyond entry-level - most people change jobs because a recruiter reaches out and they take the first offer. Strategic self-initiated job searches aligned to personality and goals would be high value.

evidenceItems.content: This is a problem that exists beyond entry-level professionals. Most people change jobs because a recruiter reaches out, and they take the first offer on the first opportunity. They don't do strategic self-initiated job searches that align to their personality and goals.

evidenceSummary: Most users have this issue but not frequent and people don't know they have the problem. One-off tool that loses value after solving. Very high emotional and objective value of solving.

applicability.justification: Most users have this issue but not frequent and don't know it's a problem. Score: 4/5

severity.justification: Significant financial impact from poor negotiations

frequency.justification: Doesn't present often - one-off tool that loses ongoing value. Score: 2/5

willingnessToPay.justification: Very high value of solving - both emotionally and objectively. Score: 5/5

retentionImpact.justification: Tool becomes less valuable after solving

strategicFit.justification: Can learn about users and build content, but not massive differentiation opportunity. Score: 3/5

title: AI Obsolescence Fear
description: Experienced professionals fear their deep, specialized expertise is becoming irrelevant due to AI, but feel "too old" or too busy to learn new technical tricks.
hypothesis: We believe this might be more relevant to an AI-specific path/solution within 2gthr.

evidenceItems.content: I suspect everyone is going to be fearing this. Everyone is speaking about this, so user might not value us over organic fixes.

evidenceSummary: Universal fear but high engagement upfront with big drop off. Everyone is talking about this so users might not value 2gthr over organic fixes. Not the strongest opportunity to build differentiation or moat.

applicability.justification: Suspect everyone is going to be fearing this. Score: 5/5

frequency.justification: High engagement upfront, big drop off. Score: 3/5

willingnessToPay.justification: Everyone is speaking about this, so users might not value us over organic fixes. Score: 3/5

retentionImpact.justification: Risk of drop off after initial engagement

acquisitionPotential.justification: Strong hook - AI anxiety is universal

strategicFit.justification: Not the strongest opportunity to build differentiation or moat. Score: 2/5

feasibility.justification: Content and courses can be built

title: Vague Rejection Silence
description: Job seekers send hundreds of applications and receive no response, preventing them from learning what is wrong with their approach.
hypothesis: We believe this is a key inflection point of whether someone becomes a MITP-person (Most Important To Progress) vs doesn't.

evidenceItems.content: I think I advocated for this one as I believe it is a key inflection point of whether someone becomes a MITP-person vs doesn't.

evidenceSummary: Low percentage of users actively looking for a job and unsure why rejected, but high value problem. Use case: once to repeatedly over 3 months, then evolves or dies. Insanely high value if we can get people into opportunities.

applicability.justification: Low percentage currently looking for a job and unsure why rejected, but high value problem. Score: 2/5

severity.justification: Extremely frustrating - prevents learning and improvement

frequency.justification: Once to repeatedly over three months, then it either evolves or dies. Score: 2/5

willingnessToPay.justification: Insanely high value of solving if we can get people into opportunities that nurture them. Score: 5/5

acquisitionPotential.justification: Strong hook for active job seekers

strategicFit.justification: Could build differentiated solution combining with other tools, content, opportunity linking. Score: 4/5

title: The "Peter Principle" Trap
description: Technical experts (engineers, accountants) are promoted into management roles where they fail because they lack the necessary leadership and people-management skills.
hypothesis: We believe that building KPI frameworks and tailored paths/guides/books/learnings would have very high value, especially for helping people understand objective measures of their management performance.

evidenceItems.content: Few people actually understand KPIs. When you interview people about how they measure their performance, they struggle to give objective indicators. There's huge value in helping people interrogate their job and understand their KPIs.

evidenceSummary: Applies to 10-12% of users (one in four managers, half face this problem). Weekly engagement possible but may fatigue after 6-12 months. Medium value due to competition from books, courses, coaches. Strong ecosystem potential.

applicability.justification: Between 10-12% of people face this (one in eight promoted to manager, or one in four with half facing the problem). Score: 1/5

severity.justification: Can lead to career failure and imposter syndrome

frequency.justification: Weekly to daily for struggling managers, but fatigues after 6-12 months. Score: 3/5

willingnessToPay.justification: Medium value - competition from books, courses, coaches, managers. Users may not put all eggs in 2gthr basket. Score: 3/5

viralCoefficient.justification: Lower sharing tendency for management struggles

strategicFit.justification: Strong ability to create mentors, testimonials, KPIs for MI to study. Score: 4/5

feasibility.justification: Complex to build tailored management guidance

timeToValue.justification: Takes time to show leadership improvement

riskLevel.justification: Competition risk from established leadership content

title: Mid-Life Discovery Confusion
description: Adults returning to the "discovery phase" later in life struggle to reconcile new interests with existing family responsibilities because they lack a framework to stress-test scenarios without risking financial ruin.
hypothesis: We believe we could build micro tools around stress testing runway, communicating frugality needs to family, and gaining support for upskilling or networking.

evidenceItems.content: This will be the first time in evolution that skills have evolved so quickly that it's not people's children learning new skills but our entire economy will have to learn new skills within their lifetimes - for some in the second half of their lifetime.

evidenceSummary: Problem is growing as skills evolve faster than generations. Low engagement - appeals to fear mongering. One-off tool with low differentiation unless we think hard about it.

applicability.justification: Growing problem as skills evolve faster than generations. Score: 3/5

severity.justification: Can lead to financial ruin if not managed

frequency.justification: Low engagement - appeals to fear mongering side of negative emotions. Score: 2/5

willingnessToPay.justification: One-off tool - could be done through ChatGPT. Not enough value without differentiation. Score: 2/5

viralCoefficient.justification: Lower sharing tendency for financial stress

strategicFit.justification: Unlocks user data (family, finances, skills) but not differentiated enough yet. Score: 3/5

title: The "Degree vs. Skill" Mismatch
description: Graduates find that their university curriculum did not teach the specific software or technical methodologies currently used by industry.
hypothesis: We believe the broader problem is overwhelm of potential tools and solutions - a huge perk would be hearing what tools people like you recommend and why, with MI guiding people to use those tools.

evidenceItems.content: The broader problem is that there is an overwhelm of potential tools and solutions available specific to your job. A huge perk would be hearing what tools people like you recommend and why they get value from using those tools.

evidenceSummary: Applies to all professions but only during transitionary periods. Low engagement - people don't like learning new software. Low value unless we can show direct job outcomes.

applicability.justification: Applies to all professions but only during transitionary periods (job changes, promotions, lateral moves). Score: 3/5

frequency.justification: Low frequency - people hate learning new software. Value diminishes quickly. Score: 3/5

willingnessToPay.justification: Low value - hard to prove we caused them to get hired because of the skill. Score: 2/5

strategicFit.justification: Not feeling confident in differentiated feature. Score: 2/5

title: The "Romanticized Reality" Trap
description: University applicants commit time and tuition to degrees based on media dramatizations (e.g., "Suits") rather than the administrative and high-stress reality of the actual role.
hypothesis: We believe this expands beyond careers to roles, companies, industries, paths - and includes whether your skills/personality/style will suit the career.

evidenceItems.content: This is relevant across several life stages however the significance decreases as you move higher. Initially for selecting a career, then for roles, clarity over leadership positions, different sized businesses, starting a business.

evidenceSummary: Relevant across life stages but significance decreases over time. More than one-off - can move from career to roles to industries to company sizes. Value is likely time value - cost of studying wrong thing.

applicability.justification: Relevant across life stages but significance decreases higher up. Score: 4/5

severity.justification: Wasted time and tuition on wrong career path

frequency.justification: More than one-off - moves from career to roles to industries. Score: 3/5

willingnessToPay.justification: Value is likely time value - cost of studying wrong thing. Score: 3/5

strategicFit.justification: Scores high with psychometric integration. Potential to compound and link to other problems. Score: varied

title: The "Professional Polish" Gap
description: Technically proficient graduates fail interviews or early probation because they lack the business etiquette, communication style, and office norms that employers demand but don't teach.
hypothesis: We believe go cards, events, courses, or experts that other platforms couldn't feasibly offer - like member meetups with workshops on business etiquette - would provide high value.

evidenceItems.content: Go cards or events or courses or experts that other platforms couldn't offer or wouldn't be feasible - like twice a year member meetups with workshops around business etiquette. Almost like the onboarding toolkit we've been thinking about building.

evidenceSummary: Most people face this early career but should learn over time. One-off event with quick value. Low perceived value if they didn't know it was a problem. High potential for unique events/content.

applicability.justification: Most people face this early career but should generally learn these skills over time. Score: 3/5

severity.justification: Can cause interview failure or probation issues

frequency.justification: One-off event with quick value delivery, why it's not a 1. Score: 2/5

willingnessToPay.justification: High objective value (getting job/interview) but low perceived value if they didn't know it was a problem. Score: 2/5

strategicFit.justification: Ranks high because of go cards, events, courses, experts that other platforms couldn't offer. Score: 3/5

title: The Stagnation Trap
description: Professionals who feel stalled lack a structured way to decide whether to push for internal promotion, change teams, or move companies, leading to years of passive drifting.
hypothesis: We believe a structured framework for mapping internal promotion benefits vs moving or changing teams would be a worthwhile tool.

evidenceItems.content: A structured framework for mapping internal promotion benefits vs moving or changing teams etc would be a worthwhile tool.

evidenceSummary: Applies to bulk of people in career progression phase. Intense engagement for short period but won't return often. High objective value but low perceived value. LLMs will likely do this better.

applicability.justification: If fluid development guide, applies to bulk of career progression phase. Score: 3/5

severity.justification: Years of passive drifting - significant career impact

frequency.justification: Intense engagement for short period, won't return often. Score: 2/5

willingnessToPay.justification: High objective value (stay vs leave decisions) but low perceived value. Score: 3/5

strategicFit.justification: Could develop content but LLMs will probably be able to take more context, sort better, and help with greater relevance. Low differentiation. Score: 2/5

title: Executive Isolation
description: Senior leaders lack a "safe" peer group to discuss sensitive issues like toxic leadership, salary negotiation, or personal doubt without losing authority.
hypothesis: We believe the platform could set this up but members may associate value more with the group than the platform.

evidenceItems.content: I struggle to see this as a worthy problem we could realistically solve well. The platform could set this up but the perceived value could be low once established as members will associate the value more with the group than the platform.

evidenceSummary: Relevant to senior positions. Definitely ongoing use but low perceived value once established - members associate value with the group not the platform. Could leverage connections and community features.

applicability.justification: Relevant to those in more senior positions - subset of users. Score: 2/5

severity.justification: Isolation can impact mental health and decision quality

frequency.justification: Definitely ongoing use for a solution that solves this. Score: 5/5

willingnessToPay.justification: Platform could set up but perceived value low once established - members associate value with group not platform. Score: 1/5

strategicFit.justification: Could leverage connections and community features. Score: 2/5

timeToValue.justification: Takes time to build trust in groups

title: Local Market Data Blindness
description: Students select degrees without visibility into local demand or pay bands, leading to qualifications in fields with zero local job openings despite global popularity.
hypothesis: We believe this permeates to a broader category - when people try to figure out what to upskill in, invest in, or whether to pivot careers, they struggle because they don't know if studying relates to job demand.

evidenceItems.content: This is a problem that permeates itself into a broader category - when people are trying to figure out what they should be upskilling in, investing, whether they should be pivoting. They struggle to take action because they don't know whether studying is related to demand for their skills.

evidenceSummary: 60% of target audience faces this problem (80% of stages, 75% of people). Strong hooks for marketing funnels around grade 10 subjects, university degree, specialization. Can retain through upskilling library with AI crawler for job opportunities.

applicability.justification: 80% of stages (student to young professional)  75% of people = 60% of target audience. Score: calculated

severity.justification: Can lead to wasted education and no job opportunities

frequency.justification: Strong attraction hooks at multiple life points (grade 10 subjects, university, articles, specialization). Weekly/monthly engagement possible. Score: 5/5

willingnessToPay.justification: Perceived value high, objective value harder to quantify. Score: 3/5

retentionImpact.justification: Can retain through continuous learning tracking

acquisitionPotential.justification: Strong marketing funnels for education decisions

strategicFit.justification: Score: t (not fully assigned in original)

feasibility.justification: Requires local market data which may be scarce

title: Conditional Self-Worth
description: High achievers experience professional setbacks (e.g., retrenchment, rejection) as personal annihilation because their identity is entirely tied to their output.
hypothesis: We believe this is something top performers (young CEOs or managers) face stronger than most, and solving it would have high perceived and objective value.

evidenceItems.content: I had rated this higher because it is something I have experienced, and I know that really top performers (young CEOs or managers) seem to face this stronger than most.

evidenceSummary: Small percentage of users face this in a given year. Once you learn to solve it, problem goes away and takes a while to resurface. High value if can build confidence back up. Other than support groups and content, hard to differentiate.

applicability.justification: Even though experienced personally, small percentage of users facing in any given year. Score: 1/5

severity.justification: Personal annihilation - very severe psychological impact

frequency.justification: Not faced often by high performers, and once solved, problem largely goes away. Score: 2/5

willingnessToPay.justification: Relatively high perceived value if can build confidence back up. Even higher objective value if results in stronger work performance. Score: 3/5

acquisitionPotential.justification: Niche hook for struggling high achievers

strategicFit.justification: Other than support groups and content, hard to build massively differentiated solution. Curious about books/retreats people use. Score: 2/5

feasibility.justification: Support groups and content are feasible
